From: "susannestaude" <staude@...>
Subject: Faulty entropy calculations?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=321663623; y=pDDYAr1SqbdM9uxLZpRAcPkVhbjeryCjVKC56c_e1GXeWIsBre3gCA
X-Yahoo-Profile: susannestaude
X-eGroups-Approved-By: dggoodwin <dgoodwin@...> via web; 27 Nov 2007 11:01:25 -0000

Hello all,

we have come across a discrepancy in the calculation of the ent=
ropy of
an ideal gas that we cannot explain:

According to the manual, the =
molar entropy using the NASA Polynomial
Parameterization is calculated as f=
ollows:

S(T)/R =3D a0*lnT + a1*T + (a2/2)*T^2 + (a3/3)*T^3 + (a4/4)*T^4 + =
a6.

If I use the coeffients given in the GRI30 mechanism for O2 and
calcul=
ate the entropy at 2000K using a calculator I get S(2000K)/R =3D
32.2356. I=
 then checked the value Cantera calculates in the following way:
In Python,=
 I type the following commands:
1. from Cantera imort *
2. gas =3D importPh=
ase('gri30.cti','gri30')
3. gas.set(Temperature =3D 2000)
4. gas.entropies_=
R()[3]  #(The index of O2 is '3')

The result is a value of 30.4285 !

I ch=
ecked this also for our mechanism on other species and the
discrepancy alwa=
ys appears when calculating the entropies at higher
temperatures.

Can some=
body explain to me how this happens?

Thanks in advance!

Susanne Staude
